data.title: Weather Alerts
data.text:
Flood Warning

Anson, NC

Richmond, NC

Stanly, NC

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is occurring. * WHERE...Portions of the southern and eastern Piedmont, Sandhills, and southern and central Coastal Plain of central North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT Friday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Rivers, creeks and streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Some roads may remain closed or impassible into the nighttime hours. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 143 PM EDT, local law enforcement reported flooding in the warned area. Between 2 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Raleigh, Durham, Fayetteville, Cary, Chapel Hill, Goldsboro, Sanford, Laurinburg, Albemarle, Southern Pines, Smithfield, Rockingham, Clinton, Wadesboro, Raeford, Mount Olive, Pittsboro, Lillington, Troy and Carthage. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Anson, NC

Stanly, NC

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Carolina... Little River At Manchester affecting Cumberland County. Rocky River Near Norwood affecting Anson and Stanly Counties. * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Rocky River near Norwood. * WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight. * IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Action Stage. The river begins to overflow its banks in some areas upstream of the gage site. At 20.0 feet, Minor flood stage. There is significant overflow into adjacent pasture and lowlands. At 27.0 feet, The parking lot at the Anson County boat access on the will begin to flood. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:45 AM EDT Friday the stage was 27.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 15.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:45 AM EDT Friday was 29.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this afternoon and continue falling to 6.1 feet Tuesday evening. - Flood stage is 20.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 28.7 feet on 03/24/1989. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Cabarrus, NC

* WHAT...Minor flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...The Rocky River in Cabarrus County, North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT Friday. * IMPACTS...Common, deeper flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to area streams is ongoing with lesser impacts to vulnerable property. Expect extensive flooding of farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Inundation may be several feet deep. Several low-water crossings, roads, and bridges may be flooded and impassible, with deeper flows over roadways possible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1234 AM EDT, Storm-total rainfall of 4-6 inches from Tropical Cyclone Debby has resulted in significant rises along the Rocky River in Cabarrus County. Tributaries feeding the Rocky River have crested and are gradually receding below Action/Advisory Stage, but the resultant floodwaves are now moving through the Rocky River, resulting in very significant rises along the Rocky River from Harrisburg to Georgeville to Midland. These rises have resulted in high-end Minor flooding with extensive impacts to low-lying areas adjacent to the river. The Rocky River may not crest for a few more hours and it will likely not fall back below Minor Flood Stage until Friday afternoon. Therefore, a Flood Warning will remain in effect through later Friday to allow the Rocky River to crest and recede below critical levels. - The following streamgauge is above Minor Flood Stage, resulting in Minor flooding along the Rocky River from Harrisburg to Georgeville... ID: IBFN7 NAME: above Irish Buffalo Creek, 5 W Georgeville CURRENT STAGE: 24.23 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 12.0 feet MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 16.5 feet MODERATE FLOOD STAGE: 26 feet TREND: Cresting. ESTIMATED FORECAST and IMPACTS: The Rocky River is currently cresting near 24.3 feet. A reasonable worst case crest of 24.5 feet cannot be ruled out by 2:00AM. At these levels, flooding is occurring near and over the intersection of Mt Pleasant Rd and NC 200 with extensive flooding of farmland and other low-lying areas along NC 200. Floodwaters are approaching and possibly flooding NC 200 with backwater effects flooding Parks Lafferty Rd. Floodwaters may also approach a driveway to a care facility at the 5300 block of NC 200, restricting access to the facility. - The Rocky River is flooding areas near the following locations... Harrisburg, Mt Pleasant, Georgeville, and Midland. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Chesterfield, SC

...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Richland, Calhoun and Lexington Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Wateree River At Lake Wateree affecting Kershaw, Fairfield and Lancaster Counties. Wateree River Near Wateree River near Camden affecting Kershaw County. Congaree River At Congaree River at Congaree NP Near Gadsden affecting Calhoun and Richland Counties. Pee Dee River At Pee Dee River at Cheraw affecting Marlboro and Chesterfield Counties. North Fork Edisto River At Orangeburg affecting Orangeburg County. * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Pee Dee River at Pee Dee River at Cheraw. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, River bottomland downstream from cheraw will begin to flood. At 30.0 feet, The higher bank begins to flood. Large areas of farmland and river bottomland near Cheraw will be flooded. Portions of Riverside Park become flooded. At 33.0 feet, Southeast of Wallace, water spreads onto Old River Road between Community Road and Highway 912. At 35.0 feet, Southeast of Wallace, Old River Road between Community Road and Highway 912 will become flooded and may need to be closed. At 36.0 feet, Extensive overflow of the left bank will occur and large areas of farmland near Cheraw will be flooded. Livestock and farm equipment should be moved to higher ground. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:15 AM EDT Friday the stage was 32.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 20.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:15 AM EDT Friday was 32.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 37.3 feet tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 30.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Lancaster, SC

...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Richland, Calhoun and Lexington Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Wateree River At Lake Wateree affecting Kershaw, Fairfield and Lancaster Counties. Wateree River Near Wateree River near Camden affecting Kershaw County. Congaree River At Congaree River at Congaree NP Near Gadsden affecting Calhoun and Richland Counties. Pee Dee River At Pee Dee River at Cheraw affecting Marlboro and Chesterfield Counties. North Fork Edisto River At Orangeburg affecting Orangeburg County. * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Wateree River at Lake Wateree. * WHEN...Until late Monday morning. * IMPACTS...At 100.4 feet, The piers on the Wildlife Road bridge over Singleton Creek become submerged. At 102.5 feet, Roadways near Beaver Creek become flooded. At 103.0 feet, Home owners on low lying property have to move belongings out of basements or from under raised houses. Boat launch on U.S. Highway 1 at the lake closed due to flood water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 99.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 100.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 102.3 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 100.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Flood Advisory

Rowan, NC

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...A portion of piedmont North Carolina, including the following county, Rowan. * WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT Friday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to N Second Creek, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1245 AM EDT, N Second Creek continues to rise above Action/Advisory Stage following storm-total rainfall of 3-5 inches resulting from Tropical Cyclone Debby. Nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas between Mount Ulla and Woodleaf is ongoing. It may take a few more hours for N Second Creek to crest and it will likely not fall back below Action/Advisory Stage until later Friday morning or early Friday afternoon. Therefore, the Flood Advisory has been extended to account for continuing nuisance flood conditions along N Second Creek. - The following streamgauge is above Action/Advisory Stage, resulting in nuisance flooding along North Second Creek.. ID: BRBN7 NAME: above Statesville Blvd (US 70), 4 mi S of Woodleaf CURRENT STAGE: 12.84 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 12.0 feet MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 14.0 feet TREND: Rising Slowly IMPACTS: N Second Creek is out of its banks up and downstream of the gauge site on US 70, flooding adjacent farmland and other low-lying areas with up to 2 feet of inundation. Woodleaf Rd is likely flooding. In fast-response situations, upstream tributaries will likely already be flooding several low-water crossings. Impacted crossings upstream may include at White Rd, Lyerly Rd, Upright Rd, Graham Rd, Hall Rd, Childers Rd, and Bear Poplar Rd. ESTIMATED FORECAST: N Second Creek will continue to rise slowly overnight and is expected to crest below 13 and 13.3 feet overnight tonight before beginning a gradual recession early Friday morning. - Some locations that may continue to experience flooding include... Cleveland, Woodleaf and Mount Ulla. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Chester, SC

* WHAT...Nuisance flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Eastern Chester County, South Carolina * WHEN...Until 800 AM EDT Friday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to Fishing Creek and Rocky Creek including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1242 AM EDT, The Rocky Creek and Fishing Creek watersheds are continuing to deal with significant flows following 2-5 inches of rainfall from Tropical Cyclone Debby. While no additional rainfall is expected, Rocky Creek and Fishing Creek will remain above Action/Advisory Stage for the next several hours, resulting in nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas. A Flood Advisory will remain in effect through at least 8:00AM to allow these streams to crest and recede below bankfull levels. Please avoid all flooded roadways and obey all barricades. Numerous roadways were closed across Chester County earlier today. Even if the roads are no longer flooded, erosion beneath the road surface may have compromised the road and could cause it to collapse under the weight of a vehicle. Turn around and find an alternative route. - Nuisance flooding may continue near the following areas... Great Falls, Richburg, and Edgemoor. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
